_link.title: I can apply the formula I = Q/t to calculate current, charge, or time

toLevel2.question: In the formula I = Q/t, what does I represent?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: In this formula, I represents electric current, measured in amperes (A). It tells us the rate at which charge flows through the circuit.

toLevel2.question: What is the correct rearrangement of I = Q/t to find the charge Q?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Multiplying both sides of I = Q/t by t gives Q = I × t. This shows that charge equals current multiplied by time.

toLevel2.question: If 10 coulombs of charge flow through a circuit in 5 seconds, what is the current?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Using I = Q/t = 10 C ÷ 5 s = 2 A. The current is 2 amperes.

toLevel2.question: What unit is used to measure electric charge?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The SI unit of electric charge is the coulomb (C). One coulomb is the amount of charge transferred by a current of 1 ampere in 1 second.

toLevel2.question: A current of 3 A flows for 10 seconds. How much charge passes through the circuit?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Using Q = I × t = 3 A × 10 s = 30 C. The total charge is 30 coulombs.

toLevel2.question: The formula I = Q/t shows that current is the rate of flow of [[charge]] through a circuit.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Current measures how much charge flows per unit time. The formula I = Q/t directly shows current as charge (Q) divided by time (t).

toLevel2.question: To find the time for a certain amount of charge to flow, use the formula t = [[Q/I]].
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Rearranging I = Q/t gives t = Q/I. Time equals charge divided by current.

toLevel2.question: When a current of 1 A flows for 1 second, exactly [[1]] coulomb of charge passes through the circuit.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Using Q = I × t = 1 A × 1 s = 1 C. This defines the relationship: 1 ampere is 1 coulomb per second.

toLevel2.question: The formula Q = I × t can be used to calculate total charge when current and time are known.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Q = I × t is the rearrangement of I = Q/t. It correctly calculates charge by multiplying current by time.

toLevel2.question: If current doubles while time stays the same, the total charge that flows will halve.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: From Q = I × t, if current doubles and time stays constant, charge also doubles. Charge is directly proportional to current.

toLevel3.question: A device draws a current of 500 mA for 2 minutes. How much charge flows through it?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: First convert: 500 mA = 0.5 A, 2 minutes = 120 s. Then Q = I × t = 0.5 × 120 = 60 C.

toLevel3.question: Why is the formula I = Q/t considered a rate equation?
toLevel3.correctAnswer: Because it shows how much of something (charge) occurs per unit of time
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Rate equations show quantity per time. Current is the rate of charge flow - how many coulombs pass a point each second.
distractors: Because it uses the ampere unit

toLevel3.question: How long would it take for 120 C of charge to flow if the current is 4 A?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Using t = Q/I = 120 C ÷ 4 A = 30 s. It takes 30 seconds for 120 coulombs to flow at 4 amperes.

toLevel3.question: A phone battery has a capacity of 10,800 C. If it discharges at a constant 1.5 A, how long will it last?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Using t = Q/I = 10,800 C ÷ 1.5 A = 7200 s = 120 minutes = 2 hours.

toLevel3.question: If 1 electron has a charge of 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C, approximately how many electrons flow per second when the current is 1 A?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: At 1 A, 1 C flows per second. Number of electrons = 1 C ÷ (1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C) = 6.25 × 10¹⁸ electrons per second.

toLevel3.question: Two circuits have the same current. Circuit A runs for twice as long as Circuit B. How do the total charges compare?
toLevel3.correctAnswer: Circuit A transfers twice as much charge as Circuit B
toLevel3.correctExplanation: From Q = I × t, if I is constant and t doubles, Q doubles. Charge is directly proportional to time when current is constant.
distractors: Circuit A transfers the same charge
Circuit A transfers half the charge
Circuit B transfers twice the charge

toLevel3.question: Charge and current are related: when current is [[constant]], charge increases linearly with time.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: For constant current, Q = I × t shows charge increases proportionally with time. Double the time means double the charge.

toLevel3.question: To convert milliamperes (mA) to amperes (A), divide by [[1000]].
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The prefix 'milli-' means one-thousandth. So 1 mA = 0.001 A, and to convert mA to A, divide by 1000.

toLevel3.question: When using I = Q/t, time must be measured in [[seconds]] for the answer to be in standard units.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The SI unit of time is seconds. Using seconds with coulombs gives current in amperes (the SI unit of current).

toLevel3.question: A battery rated at 2000 mAh can deliver a charge of 7200 C (since 2000 mA × 3600 s = 7,200,000 mA·s = 7200 C).
toLevel3.correctExplanation: mAh means milliamp-hours. 2000 mA = 2 A, and 1 hour = 3600 s. So Q = 2 A × 3600 s = 7200 C.

toLevel4.question: A capacitor discharges with a current that decreases from 2 A to 0 A over 10 seconds. Can I = Q/t with I = 2 A be used to find the total charge?
toLevel4.correctAnswer: No, because I = Q/t assumes constant current; with varying current, you need the average current or integration
toLevel4.correctExplanation: The formula I = Q/t gives average current for the total charge. Using the initial current of 2 A would overestimate the charge since current decreases.
distractors: Yes, I = Q/t always works regardless of how current changes
No, because capacitors cannot be analysed with this formula
Yes, because the formula automatically accounts for changes

toLevel4.question: A circuit has a current of 3 A for 20 s, then 1 A for 40 s. What is the total charge transferred?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Calculate each period separately: Q₁ = 3 × 20 = 60 C, Q₂ = 1 × 40 = 40 C. Total Q = 60 + 40 = 100 C.

toLevel4.question: An ammeter shows fluctuating current between 1.8 A and 2.2 A. If 400 C of charge flows, approximately how long was the current flowing?
toLevel4.correctAnswer: Approximately 200 seconds (using average current of 2 A)
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Average current ≈ 2 A. Using t = Q/I = 400 C ÷ 2 A = 200 s. The fluctuation averages out over time.

toLevel4.question: A solar panel produces 200 mA in bright sunlight for 6 hours. How much charge does it deliver?
A student calculates Q = 5 A × 2 min = 10 C. Identify and correct the error.
toLevel4.correctAnswer: Time was not converted to seconds; correct answer is Q = 5 × 120 = 600 C
toLevel4.correctExplanation: The formula requires time in seconds. 2 minutes = 120 seconds. Q = 5 A × 120 s = 600 C.
distractors: The formula should be I = Q/t
The answer should be in ampere-minutes

toLevel4.question: Two identical lamps in parallel each draw 0.5 A from a 6 V source. If they run for 1 hour, what total charge flows from the battery?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Total current = 0.5 + 0.5 = 1 A. Time = 3600 s. Q = I × t = 1 × 3600 = 3600 C.

toLevel4.question: A defibrillator delivers 360 J in 10 ms at 5000 V. Using Q = It, and knowing charge passes through the heart, what current flows?
toLevel4.correctAnswer: Cannot be directly determined from I = Q/t without first finding Q from energy and voltage
toLevel4.correctExplanation: First find Q using energy: E = QV, so Q = E/V = 360/5000 = 0.072 C. Then I = Q/t = 0.072/0.01 = 7.2 A. The question requires multiple steps.

toLevel4.question: When current varies with time, I = Q/t gives the [[average]] current over that time period.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: For varying current, dividing total charge by total time gives average current, not instantaneous current at any moment.

toLevel4.question: A battery rated in milliamp-hours (mAh) indicates total [[charge]] capacity when converted using Q = I × t.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: mAh is a unit of charge (current × time). To convert to coulombs: multiply mA by 3.6 (since 1 mAh = 0.001 A × 3600 s = 3.6 C).

toLevel4.question: For stepped changes in current, calculate charge for each [[interval]] separately, then add them together.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: When current changes in steps, apply Q = I × t to each constant-current interval, then sum all the charges to get the total.

toLevel5.question: Analyse how the formula I = Q/t relates to the definition of the ampere in terms of force between parallel conductors.
toLevel5.correctAnswer: The ampere was originally defined by the force between current-carrying wires, making I = Q/t a derived relationship showing current as charge flow rate
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Historically, the ampere was defined through electromagnetic force. The relationship I = Q/t connects this to charge, making the coulomb a derived unit (1 C = 1 A × 1 s).
distractors: I = Q/t is the fundamental definition of the ampere
Force and current are unrelated concepts
The coulomb was defined first, then the ampere

toLevel5.question: Compare the charge transfer in a 100 W light bulb running at 240 V for 1 hour versus a phone charging at 5 V, 2 A for 1 hour.
toLevel5.correctAnswer: Light bulb: Q = (100/240) × 3600 = 1500 C; Phone: Q = 2 × 3600 = 7200 C; phone transfers more charge
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Bulb current = P/V = 100/240 ≈ 0.417 A, so Q = 0.417 × 3600 ≈ 1500 C. Phone Q = 2 × 3600 = 7200 C. Despite higher power, the bulb transfers less charge due to higher voltage.
distractors: They transfer equal charge because both run for 1 hour
The light bulb transfers more charge due to higher power
Charge cannot be compared between different voltage systems

toLevel5.question: A current probe shows I(t) = 2 - 0.1t amperes over 10 seconds (starting at 2 A and ending at 1 A). Evaluate how to find total charge.
toLevel5.correctAnswer: Integrate I(t) from 0 to 10: Q = ∫(2-0.1t)dt = [2t - 0.05t²] from 0 to 10 = 15 C
toLevel5.correctExplanation: For continuously varying current, charge equals the integral of current over time. Q = 2(10) - 0.05(100) = 20 - 5 = 15 C. This equals the area under the I-t graph.
distractors: Average as Q = 1.5 × 10 = 15 C (only works for linear decrease)

toLevel5.question: Evaluate the validity of comparing battery capacities: Battery A is 3000 mAh at 3.7 V, Battery B is 2000 mAh at 7.4 V.
toLevel5.correctAnswer: Battery A stores 10,800 C of charge; Battery B stores 7,200 C; but B stores more energy (53.3 kJ vs 40 kJ)
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Charge: A = 3000 × 3.6 = 10,800 C, B = 2000 × 3.6 = 7,200 C. Energy = Q × V: A = 10,800 × 3.7 = 40 kJ, B = 7,200 × 7.4 = 53.3 kJ. Higher voltage compensates for less charge.
distractors: Battery A is better because it has more mAh

toLevel5.question: A supercapacitor is charged with constant current I until voltage reaches V. If capacitance is C, analyse how long charging takes using Q = CV and I = Q/t.
toLevel5.correctAnswer: Time t = Q/I = CV/I; charging time depends on capacitance, final voltage, and charging current
toLevel5.correctExplanation: For a capacitor, Q = CV. Substituting into t = Q/I gives t = CV/I. Higher capacitance or voltage means longer charging; higher current means faster charging.
distractors: Charging time is independent of capacitance
The formula I = Q/t doesn't apply to capacitors

toLevel5.question: In electrolysis, 2 moles of electrons are needed to deposit 1 mole of copper. If 3.2 A flows for 1 hour, analyse how much copper is deposited. (Faraday constant F = 96,485 C/mol)
toLevel5.correctAnswer: Q = 3.2 × 3600 = 11,520 C; moles of electrons = 11,520/96,485 ≈ 0.119; moles of Cu ≈ 0.06; mass ≈ 3.8 g
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Charge Q = It = 3.2 × 3600 = 11,520 C. Moles of e⁻ = Q/F = 0.119 mol. Since 2 mol e⁻ deposits 1 mol Cu: 0.06 mol Cu = 3.8 g (Cu atomic mass ≈ 63.5 g/mol).
distractors: Charge calculations don't apply to electrolysis
Copper mass equals Q directly in grams
The Faraday constant is not needed

toLevel5.question: Compare instantaneous current (i = dq/dt) with average current (I = Q/t) for a circuit where current varies sinusoidally.
toLevel5.correctAnswer: Instantaneous current changes continuously; average over a complete cycle is zero for AC, but RMS current is used for power calculations
toLevel5.correctExplanation: For AC, instantaneous current follows i = I₀sin(ωt). Average over a full cycle is zero. RMS current (I₀/√2) represents effective DC equivalent for power calculations.
distractors: Average and instantaneous current are always equal
AC current cannot be described by I = Q/t
Instantaneous current is always greater than average

toLevel5.question: Analyse why coulombs per second (C/s) is equivalent to amperes (A) but ampere-hours (Ah) measures charge, not current.
toLevel5.correctAnswer: A = C/s (rate), so A × s = C × (s/s) = C (charge); Ah = A × h is current × time = charge
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Dimensional analysis: A = C/s, so A·s = C. Similarly, A·h = (C/s)·(3600s) = 3600C. Multiplying a rate by time gives a total quantity, not another rate.
distractors: Ah and A measure the same thing
The hour is not an SI unit so Ah is meaningless

toLevel5.question: For continuously varying current, total charge is found by calculating the [[area]] under the current-time graph.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Since Q = I × t for constant current, the product represents area (height × width). For varying current, integrating I(t)dt gives the area under the curve, which equals total charge.

toLevel5.question: The relationship between charge and current can be expressed differentially as i = [[dq/dt]], meaning instantaneous current is the rate of change of charge.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: The derivative dq/dt gives instantaneous current at any moment. This is the calculus form of I = Q/t, applicable when current varies with time.
